comment_data.body:
We (also) want to show news to users that upgraded from a previous release.

It should be quite low-risk to do so, if `g:NVIM_VERSION` is older than the current version. That only happens once every 3-12 months...
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,53 @@
+-- skip when nvim is a release build
+if vim.version().prerelease ~= "dev" then

comment_data.body: can check for embedding by seeing if the TUI is (not) running. see code example at :help nvim_list_uis: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/47866cd8d20c62afa8a3c3929d3aada2db9162f5/runtime/doc/api.txt#L1072-L1074
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,53 @@
+-- skip when nvim is a release build
+if vim.version().prerelease ~= "dev" then
+  return
+end
+
+-- skip if user code explicitly disables
+if vim.g.news_check == false then
+  return
+end
+
+-- skip in embedded situations
+if vim.g.vscode or vim.g.started_by_firenvim then

comment_data.body: more robust to check for a UI (see above)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,53 @@

+if vim.version().prerelease ~= "dev" then
+  return
+end
+
+-- skip if user code explicitly disables
+if vim.g.news_check == false then
+  return

+  return
+end
+
+-- skip if nvim was started as a Lua interpreter
+if vim.list_contains(vim.v.argv, '-l') then

comment_data.body: We want to _only_ show news on version upgrade. I do NOT want to see this every time I `git pull` and build (especially when bisecting...)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,53 @@
+-- skip when nvim is a release build
+if vim.version().prerelease ~= "dev" then

comment_data.body:
> I do NOT want to see this every time I `git pull` and build (especially when bisecting...)

Of course. But I think we can devise some robust logic that only shows news when news.txt has significant changes. 

For users on HEAD it will be valuable. If it's too noisy for Nvim developers, we can either make it opt-in/opt-out, or abandon the idea. Need to see how it works in practice, first.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,53 @@
+-- skip when nvim is a release build
+if vim.version().prerelease ~= "dev" then

comment_data.body:
I'd start small: only show on version change and see if that improves things. (HEAD users -- those following HEAD, not "regular" users asked to test HEAD in a bug report) are assumed to have some familiarity with Neovim development. 

I really don't feel comfortable making developers and maintainers pay a cost for this, so I would like this to be as lightweight as possible.

(Tracking addition of news-worthy entries on HEAD would -- in essence if not in fact -- introduce a secondary version number as "seen news" counter. Not sure if that'd be worth it?)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,53 @@
+-- skip when nvim is a release build
+if vim.version().prerelease ~= "dev" then

comment_data.body:
> Tracking addition of news-worthy entries on HEAD would -- in essence if not in fact -- introduce a secondary version number as "seen news" counter. Not sure if that'd be worth it?

That's the idea. And it should signal only after some "accumulations" are seen over time (days or weeks), so that `git bisect` doesn't create false positives.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,53 @@
+-- skip when nvim is a release build
+if vim.version().prerelease ~= "dev" then

comment_data.body: This absolutely needs to be the first check.(`vim.version()` is not free).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,53 @@
+-- skip when nvim is a release build
+if vim.version().prerelease ~= "dev" then
+  return
+end
+
+-- skip if user code explicitly disables
+if vim.g.news_check == false then

@@ -0,0 +1,53 @@
+-- skip when nvim is a release build
+if vim.version().prerelease ~= "dev" then
+  return
+end
+
+-- skip if user code explicitly disables
+if vim.g.news_check == false then

comment_data.body:
> I really don't feel comfortable making developers and maintainers pay a cost for this, so I would like this to be as lightweight as possible.
> 
> (Tracking addition of news-worthy entries on HEAD would -- in essence if not in fact -- introduce a secondary version number as "seen news" counter. Not sure if that'd be worth it?)

Yes, I'm trying to keep this in mind - that's why I ditched the idea of using `vim.ui.input()` to prompt the user to see the diff of the news.txt file - it quickly became really annoying, especially as you mention in another comment when testing on older non-release versions. git bisect workflow is a great example that I'll have to think over more. I'll do some exploring here to see if I can make that work without having to add another variable/cache thing like the 'seen news'  you mention. I briefly tried this approach when I discovered myself some of these cases. It quickly became unmanageable for me in trying to track and update/compare all of it. My concession was to just throw up my hands and just notify the user "news has changed, run this command if you want to".
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,53 @@
+-- skip when nvim is a release build
+if vim.version().prerelease ~= "dev" then

comment_data.body:
> We (also) want to show news to users that upgraded from a previous release.
> 
> It should be quite low-risk to do so, if `g:NVIM_VERSION` is older than the current version. That only happens once every 3-12 months...

I'm confused by how you are using  "release" here -  do you mean a user who is on, say version [0.10.3 official release](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/commit/9b5ee7df4e45ff8abbab349468b45ad39f700c0d) and then upgrades to latest HEAD on master (for example). In this case their nvim version will now pass the  `vim.version().prerelease` test and continue on. In this case you are saying user would want to be notified? I have more questions but I'll leave it there for now :)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,53 @@
+-- skip when nvim is a release build
+if vim.version().prerelease ~= "dev" then

comment_data.body:
yes by "release" I mean 0.10.x.

> and then upgrades to latest HEAD

once they are on a non-release, it switches to "accumulate" logic: don't show news until after a few sessions (perhaps also with a minimum number of days) where the version number has incremented without decrementing.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,53 @@
+-- skip when nvim is a release build
+if vim.version().prerelease ~= "dev" then

comment_regular_data.body:
Just for reference: the main requirement of this feature is to avoid showing it for "clean" runs. The primary way of avoiding that is covered by the proposal in  https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/21431 : 

>  _do nothing_ if `g:NVIM_VERSION` was undefined / non-existant before this startup.

In other words: never show the prompt unless the current shada data indicates that this is at least the *second* time Nvim has been run.

If there are some cases that are missed by this, we can fix them later.

> avoid showing it for "clean" runs.

Right! didn't catch that `--clean` still loads builtin plugins. Added test for this.

Fixed in 3286b23

> > avoid showing it for "clean" runs.
> 
> Right! didn't catch that `--clean` still loads builtin plugins

:) By "clean" I meant all kinds of "fresh" runs: anything where shada wasn't stored in multiple sessions. In contrast, when shada "grows", that indicates this is normal "application usage", as opposed to a one-off.

I'm going to interpret the drive-by thumbs down as having issues with this implementation (original issue had no thumbs down but did have pushback in the comments). I'm happy to help work on/help with an alternative implementation, but I'm going to close this one (again...) Maybe I'll try again for a third time in another 2 years? ;)  :see_no_evil:

title: feat(runtime): news plugin for development builds
